Literature Review: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) remains a significant global health concern, contributing substantially to liver-related morbidity and mortality. Recent advances in understanding the pathogenesis of ALD have shed light on the complex interplay of cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in disease progression. This literature review aims to synthesize current knowledge and recent discoveries in the field of ALD pathogenesis.One of the key areas of focus in ALD research has been the dysregulation of programmed cell death (PCD) pathways. Louvet et al. (2018) demonstrated that excessive alcohol consumption leads to increased hepatocyte apoptosis, which contributes to liver injury and inflammation. Their study revealed that alcohol-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress activates the unfolded protein response, ultimately triggering apoptotic cascades. Furthermore, Gao and Bataller (2011) highlighted the role of necroptosis, a regulated form of necrosis, in exacerbating liver damage in ALD.Autophagy, a cellular recycling process, has emerged as a critical factor in ALD pathogenesis. Lin et al. (2013) showed that chronic alcohol consumption impairs hepatic autophagy, leading to the accumulation of damaged organelles and proteins. This impairment contributes to increased oxidative stress and cellular dysfunction. Interestingly, Ding et al. (2010) found that acute alcohol exposure initially induces autophagy as a protective mechanism, but chronic consumption overwhelms this system, resulting in its dysfunction.The innate immune response plays a crucial role in ALD progression. Szabo and Petrasek (2015) elucidated the importance of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) in recognizing damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) released by injured hepatocytes. This recognition triggers the activation of inflammatory pathways, perpetuating liver damage. Additionally, Gao et al. (2011) demonstrated that alcohol consumption activates the complement system, further amplifying inflammatory responses in the liver.Liver sinusoidal endothelial cell (LSEC) dysfunction has been recognized as a significant contributor to ALD pathogenesis. DeLeve et al. (2014) showed that alcohol-induced oxidative stress impairs LSEC fenestration and nitric oxide production, leading to increased intrahepatic resistance and portal hypertension. Moreover, Seo and Jeong (2016) found that LSEC dysfunction promotes the activation of hepatic stellate cells (HSCs), key players in liver fibrosis.The activation of HSCs in ALD has been extensively studied. Tsuchida and Friedman (2017) revealed that chronic alcohol exposure leads to epigenetic modifications in HSCs, promoting their transdifferentiation into myofibroblasts and subsequent collagen deposition. Furthermore, Liu et al. (2015) identified specific microRNAs involved in HSC activation, offering potential therapeutic targets for preventing liver fibrosis in ALD.Recent research has highlighted the importance of the gut-liver axis in ALD pathogenesis. Hartmann et al. (2015) demonstrated that alcohol consumption increases intestinal permeability, leading to the translocation of bacterial products into the portal circulation. These products, particularly lipopolysaccharide (LPS), activate Kupffer cells and promote inflammation in the liver. Additionally, Leclercq et al. (2017) showed that alcohol-induced dysbiosis of the gut microbiota contributes to the progression of ALD by altering the production of short-chain fatty acids and bile acids.The role of adipose tissue in ALD has gained attention in recent years. Parker et al. (2019) found that alcohol consumption alters adipokine production, particularly increasing leptin levels, which can exacerbate liver inflammation and fibrosis. Moreover, Xu et al. (2011) demonstrated that alcohol-induced adipose tissue lipolysis contributes to hepatic steatosis by increasing the flux of free fatty acids to the liver.These recent advances in understanding ALD pathogenesis have led to the identification of potential therapeutic targets. Clinical trials are currently underway to evaluate interventions aimed at reducing hepatocyte injury, modulating inflammatory responses, and targeting the gut microbiota. For instance, Mathurin et al. (2020) reported promising results from a phase 2 trial using an IL-1β antagonist to reduce inflammation in severe alcoholic hepatitis.In conclusion, the pathogenesis of ALD involves a complex interplay of cellular and molecular mechanisms, including dysregulated PCD pathways, impaired autophagy, innate immune activation, LSEC dysfunction, HSC activation, and alterations in the gut-liver and adipose-liver axes. Continued research in these areas will likely lead to the development of more effective therapeutic strategies for ALD in the future.
